titleStmt.title: Critical Apparatus for Lectio 1, de Fide

edition.title: Critical Apparatus for Lectio 1, de Fide

availability.p: Published under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 License

app.note: While an important addition that identifies the author of this phrase, it is also out of place. Text is clearly referring to the prologue of Lombard "in which he [Lombard] says." It seems likely that later scribes somewhat violently added Plaoul's name here as part of way identify the author of the following commentary.
We prefer the inclusion of "in" here because we think it is important read "causa" in the ablative case, and because preference is for the more explicit reading "in" helps make this clear.
While following R and SV is our default practice is equal, here we think "contra traditionem" makes more sense. Further this reading is supported by reportationes E, PV, and P
While minor our preference for the more explicit reading suggests including "quod"
The reading from witness V is chosen because of its alignment with the version of this verse found in the Vulgate
The double "est" in R and SV seems like a clear mistake, though good corroboration of the intimate relationship between these two witnesses.
While this phrase appears a bit redundant and therefore somewhat understandable that it is omitted by V, we include because it does not hurt the sense and it is supported by R, SV, and S
The choice of the subjunctive by V is unclear to us. Thus, follow the indicative reading supported by R, SV, and S

app.lem: Unde secundum Apostolum . . . ad faciem etc.
app.rdg: dicitur in praedicta diffinitione non apparentium, quia non oportet quod subiectum sit apparentium, et de hoc aliquid dicetur

app.lem: diversae viae ad imaginandum quomodo quis inducitur ad credendum articulis fidei

app.note: This is a pretty clear mistake on the part of R, and though difficult to read, SV seems to follow. If R is a descendedant of SV, then R could read as making a guess where SV was extremely unclear.

app.lem: non affectatum ad oppositum, et ultra credere articulis non est meritorium, quia non est in libera potestate voluntatis, quia quis ad credendum articulis necessatur quandoque
Prima via est Altissiodorensis. . . assensum articulorum in nobis.

app.note: We include the "originem" here because "ponit" clearly demands a direct object which is not supplied in the other witnesses.

Despite our default preference to follow R and SV, we choose the perfect tense reading, but the SV, S, and V support the use of "fecit" below and only R uses the present facit. Because we think the perfect tense is the best reading below, we are forced to choose the perfect tense reading here as well.
Despite being the only witness to include "fecit" here we choose it because it is the more explicit reading.

The meaning of the sentence clealy demands "erga se" over both "ergo" and "erga" and the text means to say "men who have this kind of love toward themselves are all citizens of the city of the devil."
Though the sense changes little, the reading in V seems to be no only the clear reading but also the more explicit.

We choose the reading from V because with think the imperfect subject use of "posset" is confusing. This is not a contrary to fact assertion, but an indicative claim: "The same can be said about the intellect with respect to truths..."
Both the sense of this sentence and the fact that R, SV and S, V are split make selection difficult. However, given the surrounding context "veritas" seems like the best selection.
We think the sentence reads better if "tam" is selected to say: "the production of such a noble habit and assent"

We think the best reading is one that treats "habitus" and "assensus" as objecitve genitives. Thus while R and SV are seem to be mistaken about "tam" above, here it is V that is mistaken about "nobiles".

It seems most likely that R and skipped from the first instance of "scribuntur" to the second and then picked up with "sine ornatu". V support the reading in Sorbonne though it leaves out "in sacra scriptura" and moves the second "scribuntur" to the end of the phrase after "eorum"

We follow S here because in this context S appears to give the most complete and accurate reading and therefore should be trusted. Moreover the sense seems to be referring to the "deocration of the muses (feminine)"
V seems to treat "scriptura" as plural to keep the parallelism with "scientiae." However, the other three witness treat "scriptura" as singular. Thus we follow them and choose "debet".

app.lem: et sic probabiles non sufficiunt...luminis naturalis igitur
app.note: Here witness S includes the identified lemma, but on completion mistakenly repeats the lemma again.

app.lem: ipsa est certior et excellentior . . .luminis naturalis, igitur

app.note: We choose to follow R and SV both because this is our default position and because we do not see a reason for the use of the imperfect subjunctive here. The sentence seems to read just find as "To the contrary, it is objected..."
We choose to leave this out because it does not seem to add anything to the text nor make anything more explicit, and it is not supported in any of the other witnesses
V makes a mistake here and repeats "ipsum a second time"
We choose this reading because we read the antecedent as "rationes" which is feminine.

app.lem: ne per ea quae credat . . creditum contra se
contra se, ne per eas reducatur

app.note: R and SV seem a little confused here. The best reading seems to be "probable reasons do many things well." The "unde" which appear quite clearly in the text could be a corruption of "bene" which is closer to the sense of "valent." But the "valent" is clearly the best reading as it offers a much needed verb to the opening clause.
All witnesses clearly write "insultu" but this is not a word. "insulto" is the proper ablative for insultus
We choose to include as part of preference for the more explicit reading. We think it helps make the sense slightly clearer.
We choose "eorum" because we see the antecedent as the "haereticos et gentiles" previously mentioned
With the dative "articulis" is more fitting with the use of "assentiendum" than the accusative "articulos"

app.lem: quia ex illis potest generari habitus qui inclinabit ad assentiendum articulis. Tamen talis habens habitum talem
non habens tamen infusum habitum fidei
app.rdg: non tamen haberet fidem et sic tales

app.note: The singluar is better here given the singular verbs and participles used immediately before (e.g. "habens")

This selection is difficult given the mix of tenses that proceed it. The imperfect subjunctive "crederet" suggests continuing to use the imperfect subjective as part of the contrary to fact conditional. But the present subjunctive "incipiat" suggest something like a mix of the "future more vivid" and "future less vivid." In the end we choose "haberet" since it is supported by more witnesses.

app.lem: esset ibi propter Deum, ut si aliquis canonicus. . . ad errorem diminuendum
app.rdg: cantat et est in devotione propter Deum

app.note: While the difference is slight, "cui" is supported by two witness SV and S, while "ubi" is only supported by R.

app.lem: Item, valent ad infirmitatem. . . est per luminem supernaturale

app.note: Since the meaning is more or less the same and R and SV differ on this reading, we choose the reading supported by the most witnesses

Since there is no consensus here we have chosen the reading suggested by R. We see "morbus" as a predicative nominative describing "peccatum," thus it should be in the nominative case. Likewise, we prefer ipsius over ipsum because besides the fact that "ipsum" does not match the nominative masculine form of "morbus," it also makes better sense to see it as a pronoun for "intellectus" rather an intensifier of "morbus"
We choose the V reading beacuse is closer to the version of this first found in the Vulgate.

app.lem: Unde sicut potio amara . . . et roborat intellectum
licet credere sit ex parte actus intellectus ut declarabo. Patet ergo quod fides sit meritum

app.note: Though it only appears in the V witness, we include it because of our preference for the more explicit reading.

app.lem: sicut e converso, principalius fides pertinet et est actus intellectus, etiam pertinet ad voluntatem

app.rdg: volens credere aut non ut volens

app.note: In V alio modo is repeated twice

corr.del: indignitatis creaturae auffert duas secundas habitudines et non primam et sic illa et sic illa fides mortua est

app.note: Here we show our preference for the more explicit reading
V's reading is preferable because the use of "quasi" helps us to see that faith makes probable reasons to be like or "as if" demonstrative.
"theologi" is preferred because Plaoul is talking about "faithful theologians." Thus we need the world "theologians" not "theological."

app.lem: Unde et de hoc est unus
app.note: We think the best reading is the one that in V which includes the "unde" as transition to the next claim

app.lem: vel non est, oratio vera vel falsa dicitur
app.note: Here again we choose the most explicit reading, founding ms V

app.lem: quod sibi non potest subesse falsum

app.note: We prefer to include "et" here because we think it should read: "so also"
We follow V here because we do not see any strong reason to prefer the imperfect tense over the present

app.rdg: Et de istis non plus pro nunc
app.note: Which choose to exclude this final line since it is appears like a line proper to a "reportatio" which would likely be removed during later revisions as appears to be the case in R, SV, and S.
